Much of the problem in some of these discussions seems to result from a misunderstanding of the nature of science; what science is and how it works. As a result, some ask for "proof" of scientific theories, unaware that no theory of science ever reaches the point of logical proof. 
 
 Perhaps it would be beneficial to consider how scientists view science, and particularly how evolutionary biologists look on the theories of evolution. In that light, consider the following:
 
 First, a scientist assumes that the world can be understood. He/she assumes that there are patterns that can be analyzed and studied to result in broad principles that can be applied everywhere, at all times. This is the assumption that the universe is a single system where the basic rules apply everywhere. The theories of gravity that explain how the planets move around the sun also apply to planets moving around other stars.
 
 Second, a scientist assumes that all ideas are subject to change. If science held fast to unchangeable dogma, then scientific advance would stop. Scientific knowledge is a set of inferences based on observed data and tests of those inferences. As additional or more refined observations are made, the explanations must be tested and expanded, altered, or in a few cases, rejected, in order to account for the new observations.
 
 Third, scientific knowledge lasts. While admitting a certain amount of uncertainty because of the logical construct of scientific knowledge, there is still the assumption that well tested ideas will continue to hold and can be used as the basis for advance. Thus, Newton's laws of gravity, based on previous work by Copernicus, Kepler and Galileo, were themselves adjusted by Einstein. In effect, Newton's work became a subset of limited application within the more general theory of gravity.
 
 Finally, science can't know everything. There are matters that are outside the scope of science. Some things, by their very nature, cannot be examined by science. Thus miracles, fortune-telling, astrology, and superstitions cannot be scientifically examined unless they produce empirical, repeatable observations. In fact, such topics claim to be exceptions to natural universe. They claim to be supernatural and are thus, by definition beyond examination by science. They can be neither "proved" (nor supported, for that matter), or disproved by science.
 
 So how does science work? First there is an observation or several observations. Then, based on knowledge of previous science, imagination, and invention, a scientist proposes a plausible explanation that accounts for all of the observations, and fits into or adjusts current scientific knowledge. This is called the hypothesis.
 
 From this hypothesis, a prediction is made as to an additional observation can must be true as a logical consequence of the hypothesis. Stated another way, if the predicted observation is made it offers evidence that the hypothesis is true. However, if the prediction turns out to be false, then the hypothesis must be false. It must be rejected or possibly restated to account for the failure of the predicted observation. This is known as the principle of falsifiability. A scientific hypothesis (or theory) must have this property. It must be possible to prove that it is wrong. If no possible conditions exist under which the hypothesis can be shown to be wrong, it is not falsifiable and is probably not science.
 
 If supported, then the hypothesis is tentatively accepted. A severely tested hypothesis is known as a theory. This is not the "theory" that is commonly meant in general use. Objections to the teaching of valid science in our schools because it is, after all, "only a theory" try to represent science as a wild guess based on no evidence. Strangely, it seems that only certain scientific ideas are objected to on that basis. You don't see objections to the teaching of the sun as the center of the solar system on the basis of it being "only a theory." No one claims that the atomic nature of matter taught as the basis of chemistry and nuclear physics is "only a theory." And no one ever supports the teaching of the four elements (fire, water, earth, and air) seeking their predetermined level as an alternative to the "theory" of gravity.
 
 For those who follow to this point, I can present an examples of science working in exactly the way I have outlined above. I can even offer examples of evolutionary biology working in exactly this way. But first, should we clarify any of the above?
